content.2: I know it is so of a truth: but how should man be just with God?
content.3: If he will contend with him, he cannot answer him one of a thousand.
content.5: Which removeth the mountains, and they know not: which overturneth them in his anger.
content.6: Which shaketh the earth out of her place, and the pillars thereof tremble.
content.7: Which commandeth the sun, and it riseth not; and sealeth up the stars.
content.8: Which alone spreadeth out the heavens, and treadeth upon the waves of the sea.
content.9: Which maketh Arcturus, Orion, and Pleiades, and the chambers of the south.
content.10: Which doeth great things past finding out; yea, and wonders without number.
content.11: Lo, he goeth by me, and I see him not: he passeth on also, but I perceive him not.
content.12: Behold, he taketh away, who can hinder him? who will say unto him, What doest thou?
content.14: How much less shall I answer him, and choose out my words to reason with him?
content.15: Whom, though I were righteous, yet would I not answer, but I would make supplication to my judge.
content.16: If I had called, and he had answered me; yet would I not believe that he had hearkened unto my voice.
content.17: For he breaketh me with a tempest, and multiplieth my wounds without cause.
content.18: He will not suffer me to take my breath, but filleth me with bitterness.
content.19: If I speak of strength, lo, he is strong: and if of judgment, who shall set me a time to plead ?
content.20: If I justify myself, mine own mouth shall condemn me: if I say , I am perfect, it shall also prove me perverse.
content.22: This is one thing , therefore I said it , He destroyeth the perfect and the wicked.
content.23: If the scourge slay suddenly, he will laugh at the trial of the innocent.
content.24: The earth is given into the hand of the wicked: he covereth the faces of the judges thereof; if not, where, and who is he?
content.25: Now my days are swifter than a post: they flee away, they see no good.
content.26: They are passed away as the swift ships: as the eagle that hasteth to the prey.
content.27: If I say, I will forget my complaint, I will leave off my heaviness, and comfort myself:
content.28: I am afraid of all my sorrows, I know that thou wilt not hold me innocent.
content.30: If I wash myself with snow water, and make my hands never so clean;
content.31: Yet shalt thou plunge me in the ditch, and mine own clothes shall abhor me.
content.32: For he is not a man, as I am, that I should answer him, and we should come together in judgment.
content.33: Neither is there any daysman betwixt us, that might lay his hand upon us both.
content.34: Let him take his rod away from me, and let not his fear terrify me:
